B000AL730O|4.0|As a die-hard Paul and Beatles fan of many years, I have been anxiously waiting for the release of this new CD. I guess, I expected the usual balance of upbeat catchy rockers and beautiful ballads. I couldn't wait, so I rushed to listen to some poor-quality demos available online. I was in for a surprise. The first impression: disappointment. The music just didn't grab me, and I found myself impatiently skipping to the end of each song hoping to find that the next one will carry me away. It just didn't work the first time. Then I bought the CD (I _am_ a loyal fan, did I mention that? :) ) and gave it a good listen, this time - on a high-end stereo - and with a different attitude. I was amazed how much the songs touched me this time. It is, clearly, a different Paul. Mature, philosophical, a bit sad, but still hopeful and optimistic. The pace of the record is unusual for McCartney, it is more like something you'd expect from James Taylor, or, perhaps, even the recent Mark Knopfler. I had the same experience with the latest Mark Knopfler's CD - Shangri-La. The songs don't rock, they won't necessarily grab a casual listener who doesn't pay attention. However, if you _do_ listen, you immediately get mesmerized by the beauty and intelligence of the songs, you savor each sounds, each guitar lick, you recognize the genius behind the music.   This CD definitely contains some great acoustic guitar songs that, I know, I would enjoy playing on a winter night, sitting by the fireplace with my guitar, occasionally sipping a single malt. If you expect the likes of Helter-Skelter, Sgt Pepper, Beware My Love, She's A Woman, etc., you might be dissapointed. But if you can appreciate Winter Rose, Little Lamb Dragonfly, Teddy Boy, Blackbird, She's Leaving Home... the list goes on and on (it's Macca we're talking about) - you're in for a treat.  As for the rock-n-roll... I can't wait till next Tuesday when I see my boy Paul in concert in Boston! I've seen many live shows including theStones, but no one rocks like Paul McCartney in concert! The only people who disagree are the ones who haven't seen his live shows.

0316548189|5.0|Mandela, in his autobiography \\"Long Walk To Freedom\\" has become an inspiration to me as a young African man. His humble beginnings with his mum at Qunu and later with his uncle, the regent, at Mqhekezweni, is typical of most Africans, me included.<br /><br />The \\"Long Walk To Freedom\\" is a book that brings out the brutal honesty of a man who's hunger for freedom overwhelms his desire to settle down at \\"...8115 Orlando East\\" with his family, and practice law at his \\"Mandela & Tambo\\" Law Firm, with the current Apartheid System of Government. It introduces us to the History of South Africa as a Nation under the brutal minority rule (Whiteman's rule). It open's our eyes to the continuation of his struggle against the Apartheid system even in the prisons he was sent to - Pretoria Local, Marshall Square & Robben Island. His struggle to remain sane in the face of apparent mistreatment from warders who were ordered to make his life unbearable.These warders were also ill informed on the reasons for his incarceration. While Apartheid had thrived for three centuries, he was determined not to let it survive his life time and devoted his life to make this happen.<br /><br />What stands out, is his loyalty to the ANC. In prison and out of prison he undertakes the task of teaching the people ANC policies, like a preacher devoted to teaching people about Jesus no matter his circumstances. Even in his talks to the government - who are bent on changing his view point - he refuses to accept anything short of what the ANC has been fighting for all along. The world has lessons to learn from the \\"Long Walk To Freedom\\". I recomend it to anyone who can get his hands on it.

B000002I2M|5.0|I've loved the Doors since I was a toddler, but it was relatively recently that I started collecting their albums.  This being said, L.A. Woman is essential to any Doors fan; it is not only the final effort of the original lineup and, therefore, a piece of musical history, but it marks a genuine return to form for the band.  The first three studio albums were excellent and unique releases, while the fourth and fifth were of debatable musical quality.  However, L.A. Woman proves that the band did not lose their creative edge, opting instead to go out with a bang!   <br /> <br />There has been much commentary regarding the \\"change\\" in Jim Morrison's singing on this album.  While it is probably true that Jim's hard living aged him a few decades since the Doors' first album, the \\"craggy, worn-out\\" vocals he utilizes in songs such as \\"Been Down So Long\\" and \\"L.A. Woman\\" appear to be little more than a stylistic change  (and not a bad one, I might add).  If this is not the case, then why do \\"L'America,\\" \\"Hyacinth House,\\" and \\"Riders on the Storm\\" feature Mr. Morrison's trademark smooth baritone?  Many have also commented on the strong blues influence found in L.A. Woman, stating as well that the Doors could no longer be classified as psychedelic (even though this label itself was very limiting to such a creative rock group and, therefore, somewhat inaccurate).  While it is true that L.A. Woman is probably the band's most blues-influenced album, it can hardly be classified as standard blues rock; there are still plenty of psychedelic touches on at least half, if not most, of the songs, not to mention the dark undercurrent that continues to distinguish the band decades after their time.  Besides, the strong influence of the blues is present on every single one of their prior releases.   <br /> <br />And now for the music itself!  \\"The Changeling\\" is an excellent opener; it is a fairly standard blues rocker, but it is executed with plenty of power and gusto, and the psychedelic interlude is a nice touch.  \\"Love Her Madly,\\" a bluesy, honkytonk rocker, is also a very good song, with some trademark Doorsesque organ thrown in the middle.  Other highlights include the raunchy title track, the creepy \\"L'America,\\" and \\"The WASP,\\" a cross between a spoken word piece and a strong blues rocker.  \\"Crawling King Snake,\\" which I believe to be a cover of a blues song, is, in my opinion, an excellent effort by the Doors.  It features some of the greatest and most innovative guitar work by Robbie Krieger, fusing blues leads with jarring dissonance that predates dissonant post-punk guitar from the late seventies/early eighties- it is unique even for the Doors!  The only really weak song is \\"Cars Hiss By My Window,\\" as it is a real snoozer.  And last, but certainly not least, is the brooding \\"Riders on the Storm,\\" a calm and jazzy (but trippy) number with a sprinkling of psychedelic flavor that serves as the perfect closer for the album.  Ironically, the song, as well as the album itself, also works as a beautiful farewell from one of the greatest and most unique rock acts of the 20th century.
6304602979|5.0|This film is great.  Best work from Tony Scott.  And this director's cut even better than the original seen on TV. <br />The end of the film should be the only reason to see this film. <br />Best end in years.
B00005Q66T|5.0|It's not often that a recording artist can actually stay true to the title of \\"Greatest Hits\\", while actually including all hits. See recent Hits packages by Hilary Duff, Michael Jackson, and Mariah Carey, where remixes, b-sides, flopped singles alternate cuts, and even non-singles must be added to fill up the disc.  It's even more rare for an artist to be able to fill a SECOND greatest hits package, without any overlap, and STILL have certifiable hits left off.<br /><br />GHV2 starts out where The Immaculate Collection left off, 1992.<br /><br />Deeper & Deeper hit #7 on the charts (#1 in Dance) and was the second single off of Erotica. It was a disco flavored house / pop hybrid.<br /><br />Erotica, the controversial, dark lead off single from the album of the same name, hit #3 (#1 in Dance). Human Nature hit #46, but was #2 in sales and in huge rotation on MTV & VH-1.<br /><br />Secret, the lead off single from Bedtime Stories, hit #3 (#1 Dance) is up next. Don't Cry For Me Argentina hit #8 (#1 Dance), is included in ballad form, not the Miami Dance Remix that was also very popular in the clubs.<br /><br />GHV2 then dips back to Bedtime Stories again with the way ahead of its time \\"Bedtime Story\\", the 3rd single from the album. It hit #42 (#1 Dance). We then skip to the 3rd US single from Ray Of Light, the hyperballad \\"Power Of Goodbye\\". It peaked at #11.<br /><br />\\"Beautiful Stranger\\" the glouriously delicious throwback to the 70's, hit #16 (#1 Dance, #1 Sales), follows. \\"Frozen\\" is up next. The lead of single from Ray Of Light hit #2 (#1 Dance, #1 Sales).<br /><br />We go back to the Bedtime Story album with \\"Take A Bow\\", which spent 11 weeks at #1, as well as 9 weeks at the top Sales spot. \\"Ray Of Light\\" (#5, #1 Dance, #1 Sales) follows.<br /><br />The stuttering \\"Don't Tell Me\\" comes up next and hit #4 (#1 Dance, #1 Sales). \\"What It Feels Like For A Girl\\" is next. It hit #23 (#1 Dance, #1 Sales). Drowned World wasn't released in the US, but this set was also intended for international release and it hit #10 in the UK. It's ashame this wasn't released in the US, as it is one of the most touching, heartfelt songs in her catalouge. \\"Music\\" the biggest hit in her 2nd decade in music finishes off the collection. It hit #1 (#1 Dance, #1 Sales, #1 Airplay) and stayed there for 4 weeks.<br /><br />With so many huge hits filling the disc, again, as with the first Hits set, legitimate hits had to be left off. These include \\"This Used To Be My Playground\\" (#1), Bad Girl (#36), I'll Remember (#1), You'll See (#6), You Must Love Me (#18), and American Pie (#29).<br /><br />All in all, GHV2 is a true testament to the power of Madonna. There are only 2 other artists who have had more Top 10's & Top 40's than her, Elvis & The Beatles. GHV2 will take you back to wherever you were when they were released, and you'll love every minute of it.was also intended for international release and it hit #10 in the UK. It's ashame this wasn't released in the US, as it is one of the most touching, heartfelt songs in her catalouge. \\"Music\\" the biggest hit in her 2nd decade in music finishes off the collection. It hit #1 (#1 Dance, #1 Sales, #1 Airplay) and stayed there for 4 weeks.  <br /> <br />With so many huge hits filling the disc, again, as with the first Hits set, legitimate hits had to be left off. These include \\"This Used To Be My Playground\\" (#1), Bad Girl (#36), I'll Remember (#1), You'll See (#6), You Must Love Me (#18), and American Pie (#29).  <br /> <br />All in all, GHV2 is a true testament to the power of Madonna. There are only 2 other artists who have had more Top 10's & Top 40's than her, Elvis & The Beatles. GHV2 will take you back to wherever you were when they were released, and you'll love every minute of it. <br />
B0002OERI0|5.0|Green Day to me has rarely been an album band. Many bands like say Pearl Jam or many U2 records song-to-song never falters. There's always a level of consistency. Not the case with Green Day. You'll have 3 strong songs then crap for a couple then one good, then couple more crap. I even can't stand most of their Hits album. But this actually is a very consistent record. While the songs may not be instant faves, there is a level of \\"well it's not that bad\\".    American Idiot: First single and while it is a good song, it's not really a good representation of the album. This could've easily fit on Nimrod or Insomniac. One of my favorite little bits is after the chords he adds in a little \\"stab\\" at the higher strings. Good but not awesome. 8.5/10    Jesus of Suburbia: One of the album's 2 long songs with 5 sections each and this one flows the best. My favorite section is the I Don't Care one and Tales from Another Broken Home. The Dearly Beloved section nearly derails the entire thing though. 9/10    Holiday: Incredibly overplayed I can't stand it anymore. It's a good song, good beat but god I can't hear it anymore. It does work as a song though and if you're new to the song you'll like it but for the rest of us with video stations and radio, you can't stand another listen. 8/10    Boulevard of Broken Dreams: Segues from Holiday nicely with some tremolo guitar and a catchy guitar line during the verses. One thing does disturb me though: the chorus chords are exactly the same as Holiday's chorus except the order is different. 8/10    Are We the Waiting: Green Day's attempt at making a big stadium sing-along but it sounds eerily similar to Youth of the Nation personally. It's not a bad song, just not a standout either. 7/10    St. Jimmy: I used to skip this but after seeing it performed on Storytellers I started to like it more. The dawning of our lives line is similar to Holiday though which of course I can't stand anymore. 8/10    Give Me Novacaine: One of those unsung album songs that doesn't really get attention until you sit through the entire album. It's a nice song, sung very well with almost tropical(best way to describe it) sounding chords. 7.5/10    She's a Rebel: Another rocker but I don't like it that much. I can't put my finger on it but I never did like it. Not much to say about it either. 7/10    Extraordinary Girl: Different sounding song with an Egyptian flavor but I don't know, never really liked this one either. Just doesn't appeal to me much. 7/10    Letterbomb: This is probably the oddest song on the album I actually like. It's not insanely catchy, takes awhile to get to the chorus but it's actually quite good. 7.5/10    Wake Me Up When September Ends: When compared to the other \\"ballads\\" the band's done like Macy's Day Parade and Good Riddance, it's not that great. Guitar is nice, vocals are simple yet emotional but something oddly turns me off. 7.5/10    Homecoming: The other 9 minute 5 part song and it doesn't flow as well as Jesus but it does have my favorite section of all of them: The final half of last section Coming Home Again where it gets all anthemic then it gets Zeppelin/military style. Awesome ending but the rest is just merely good. 8/10    Whatsername: Probably my favorite album closer ever beside Macy's Day Parade. Very laid-back until it gets big and awesome including the final verses. It seems rather odd to close the song rather than the ending of Homecoming but the \\"bigness\\" of this ending just fits and that final D chord sounds better than that damn kid from Homecoming. 9.5/10    If you're into Green Day, definately check this out. If you're into \\"punk\\" such as Black Flag or Dead Kennedy's well take a chance or try it out online but this is an album to listen to.

B00005JKES|5.0|Too bad it couldn't have been renewed for the originally-intended 3rd season.  For the purposes of this review, I will concentrate on the series itself rather than the DVD value/quality; suffice it to say that I am less than thrilled that I was forced to buy a crappy Japanese import of the pilot, complete with ridiculously bad, unremovable English subtitles.   <br /> <br />Twin Peaks is vintage David Lynch, and all David Lynch fans (we are a rabid bunch) are guaranteed to cherish this show.  But it's appeal extends beyond that niche.  It is a murder mystery/soap opera, but this doesn't even scratch the surface.  Never have so many elements combined to make a show so compelling.  The murder mystery has some obvious Lynch trademarks, punctuated with creepy, meaningful shots, such as the spinning ceiling fan or the infamous domino.  The soap elements somehow blend in seamlessly, and that is a triumph.  When you are first watching the show, it is nearly impossible to know what will directly relate to the \\"who killed Laura Palmer\\" question and what doesn't, but everything has meaning.  There are no throw-away moments here.   <br /> <br />The element of Twin Peaks that is probably most enduring, having worked it's way into pop culture lore, is Kyle McLachlan's performance as FBI Special Agent Dale Cooper.  His hokey, folksy declarations about cherry pie and Douglas Firs give way, suddenly at times, to the intense visions and startling realizations that both disturb and excite a psychic like Cooper.  Did I catch you off-guard with that, if you haven't seen the series?  This important point is introduced just as casually in the show; Cooper acts as if it is a given that he is psychic and never bothers to \\"announce\\" this fact.  He is also highly intuitive and logical, a multiple threat of a detective.  All portrayed convincingly by McLachlan, one of the most underrated actors of our time. <br /> <br />Twin Peaks, of course, is a place where the more wholesome something seems, the more it actually isn't.  This is a theme that has been explored in countless books, films and shows, but never as effectively.  There are a few storylines that stand out (all will be related in the end) in the first season:  Agent Cooper and Sheriff Truman's investigation, of course, but also the continuing saga of Leland Palmer's deteriorating mental state.  There is undercover bad girl Audrey Horne's brazen snooping, not to mention her bordering-on-inappropriate yet exciting flirtation with Agent Cooper (and his barely restrained mutual attraction).   <br /> <br />I'll move on now to one of my favorite subplots in order to give an idea of what to expect from this show, the surprisingly compelling illicit relationship of high-school football hero/boyfriend of Laura Palmer Bobby Briggs and high-school dropout diner waitress Shelley Johnson, who just so happens to be married to a psychopath who may have had a hand in Laura's murder.  Here, David Lynch has taken something that could be overwrought and labored, as it would be on a soap opera, and made it one of the more suspensful subplots.  This highlights another of the show's great performances, Dana Ashbrook as Bobby.  This portrayal is rather difficult to describe.  From afar, Bobby appears to be the perfect popular boy--the quarterback with the prom-queen girlfriend.  Closer up, he appears to be a belligerent, smart-assed punk with little respect for authority and a penchant for getting himself involved in the darker side of Twin Peaks.  It is only in the scenes with Shelley that you realize that he is not as tough as he first appears, and beyond a doubt gentle and loving with women--it really is rather shocking.  The willigness of the seemingly selfish, cavalier Bobby to put himself in danger in order to protect Shelley from her abusive husband makes for some compelling viewing.  I really can't believe I'm writing this about an \\"affair storyline,\\" one of many on this show.  But that is David Lynch for you.You always know the characters Lynch is fond of, certainly Cooper, but the train-wreck Bobby Briggs as well.  Watch out for some of Bobby's signature quotes, some of the funniest on the show--\\"All of you hypocrites make me SICK!!\\" (Tastefully screamed at Laura Palmer's funeral).  Or the way he casually puts a cigarette in his mouth as his war veteran father attempts to have a \\"man-to-man\\" with him.  Look to Bobby and Agent Cooper for some of the series' wittier moments. <br /> <br />I could go on forever higlighting all of the things that make this show great, but it really is something you have to experience for yourself.  It is the kind of thing that sticks with you days after you watch it, and you will feel personally connected with and attached to the well-developed characters. <br /> <br />If you have an open mind, devour this DVD.  You won't be disappointed (except for the lack of the pilot--you HAVE to wathch it first and will unfortunately have to look for it seperately).

B000007RV5|3.0|I first heard this back in 1998, and I was overwhelmed by the raw sound this album contained. This is one of my all time favorite hard rock albums. Well... back then, I did not know that Fred Durst is an idiot. <br /> <br />This is best described as an \\"attitude album\\" (so are all other LB releases). Anybody who ONLY listens to serious music should stay away from this. The guitar, bass, drum playing are exceptional except that the vocal has nothing to spew but childish rants. It's fun. <br /> <br />It is SUPPOSED TO BE FUN! <br /> <br />...until Fred started saying at awards shows that \\"music is everything, music touches the soul... blablabla\\". Yeah right, people get touched in the soul when told to \\"get the f* up\\" or \\"I did it all for the nookie\\". The stupid lyrics wouldn't have mattered if Fred himself chose not to be taken seriously. <br /> <br />So there you have it--- critics and haters everywhere. If only Fred would just shut the hell up and maybe this band could've had a better reputation at present. <br /> <br />I just want to be completely honest with a few things: <br /> <br />1) In this album, Fred CAN rap. He's got some flow however little on most of the tracks here (\\"Pollution\\", \\"Counterfeit\\", \\"Stuck\\"). Saying he can't rap is an overstatement- and you know it. Hatred blinds you for the most part. <br /> <br />2) I cannot stress this any more clearer: STOP TAKING THIS BAND SERIOUSLY! If you want serious music, stop thinking Fred can give you that. Fred Durst can rot in hell, but this band's all about having fun. If you have gone to some of their concerts (before the damage done to the band's image became irreparable--- that is, sometime before 2001) it's all about dynamics. People enjoyed their live shows then. Today, I honestly do not know how the people would take it if they see Fred Durst on stage again. <br /> <br />3) For those saying Wes, Sam, Otto suck at what they do, again you are blinded by hatred. They are truly the reason why the band is popular. Wes is truly the talent of the band. He is innovative and his riffs are catchy apart from heavy. Sam has a unique groove to his playing... perfectly fits a rap-rock band. And otto, so far he's the only drummer of a mainstream band with the best groove- although at times his style can get predictable, but nonetheless, he is a good drummer. I just hate hearing comments that \\"Otto sounds like he just got out of his fourth drum lesson\\". These comments are all too stereotypical, I pity the commentator. <br /> <br />Anybody who wants to listen to hard rock as raw as it gets, get this album. If you're more into lyrics, go get Incubus instead. Lastly, if you hate Limp Bizkit that much, get over it and see the talent of the people behind Fred Durst's shadow. <br /> <br />Peace and love.

B00005JOHU|4.0|I'm going to borrow an analogy used in the recent Supreme Court confirmation hearings for a moment. When Nicholas Cage comes up to bat, he frequently hits singles or misses, but when he hits a homerun, it is usually out of the ballpark. Cage has certainly made his share of crappy (\\"Gone in 60 Seconds\\") or mediocre films (\\"The Family Man\\"), but he has also, occasionally, made really good films. Films that he should be proud of. Films that would do a Nicholas Cage Film Festival proud. \\"Lord of War\\" is such a film.<br /><br />Directed by Andrew Niccol (the writer of \\"The Truman Show\\" and the writer/director of the underappreciated \\"Gattaca\\" and the rightfully forgotten \\"Simone\\"), \\"War\\" is a dark comedy that falters only once or twice. This coupled with a terrific performance by Cage make it a memorable film. Whether it becomes a remembered film has yet to be seen.<br /><br />Yuri Orlov (Cage) and his brother Vitale (Jared Leto) are second generation Ukrainian immigrants helping their Catholic parents run a Kosher restaurant in the Little Odessa neighborhood of New York. One day, Yuri witnesses a gang shootout and realizes that money can be had from selling guns. He talks Vitale into partnering with him and they start a business taking them into war zones across the globe. As the money rolls in, each spends on their vice of choice; Vitale starts snorting profit through his nose and Yuri romances Eve (Bridget Moynahan), a famous model from the old neighborhood. After they are married, the Cold War ends and business really picks up. A zealous ATF agent (Ethan Hawke) sets his sights on Yuri.<br /><br />Reportedly based on true events, \\"War\\" is a fast-paced, darkly comic look at a man we should loathe.<br /><br />Cage's performance is great. The film begins with Yuri breaking the fourth wall; addressing the audience from the screen, talking about his business and his morals (\\"I never sold guns to Osama Bin Laden. Not on moral grounds, just at that time, his checks were always bouncing.\\") setting the tone for his character and the film. Throughout the film, Yuri frequently provides narration which is light and breezy, a brilliant counterpoint to the subject matter. This also helps to make his character more memorable, because what he says is usually completely at odds with what we should be feeling or experiencing. Somehow, and I'm not entirely sure how he does it, Cage makes Yuri a sympathetic guy. Yuri is a drug runner who sells weapons and helps keep wars going so he can make more money. He occasionally uses drugs and also cheats on his wife, Eve. Yet, we care for him. When he gets into dangerous situations, we want him to get out safely. How did Cage accomplish this? Part of it is that we see him in dangerous situations. Other people die. The danger is there. Things happen to him. He isn't completely unaffected either. Because we feel for him, we laugh at ourselves for being taken in by this character which in turn adds to the dark humor.<br /><br />Niccol manages to tell a political story, without preaching. We learn or witness as the story unfolds. The beginning sequence, a terrific point of view shot of the journey of a single bullet from manufacture to use also helps to quickly establish what Niccol is trying to do. He uses Yuri as his mouthpiece, serious at times and completely unaffected at others. Because we are watching the events through this character's eyes, it would be impossible for the film to be very preachy. Yuri wouldn't stand around and preach about this or that, so Niccol doesn't either. Even though Yuri frequently makes statements about his impartiality to one conflict or the other, his statements and what he witnesses inform us. Parts of the story are serious and others are satirical. Niccol maintains this blend well throughout faltering only a few times in the last act.<br /><br />The supporting cast is good. Jared Leto is convincing as Vitale, Yuri's coked out, out of control younger brother. Bridget Moynahanis also good as Eve, Yuri's wife, who doesn't face the truth until forced to. Ian Holm makes a brief appearance as an old school gunrunner, Yuri's main competition.<br /><br />Ethan Hawke's role as Agent Valentine is little more than a glorified cameo. Hawke starred in Niccol's first film \\"Gattaca\\" and I get the sense they wanted to work together again, no matter the project. It seems as though Valentine is meant to be the character who reflects was we should be feeling, the conscience of the audience. In his few moments on screen, he says what we should say; he displays the disgust we should feel. But the character is, as mentioned, only on screen for a brief period. Thankfully. If the character did work, providing a Yang to balance Cage's Ying, the film would lose a significant amount of its dark humor. It's a small role and odd that they would use his name in the advertisements.<br /><br />\\"Lord of War\\" is not a perfect film, but it is a memorable one and it contains a great performance from Nicholas Cage.get Moynahan is also good as Eve, Yuri's wife, who doesn't face the truth until forced to. Ian Holm makes a brief appearance as an old school gunrunner, Yuri's main competition. <br /> <br />Ethan Hawke's role as Agent Valentine is little more than a glorified cameo. Hawke starred in Niccol's first film \\"Gattaca\\" and I get the sense they wanted to work together again, no matter the project. It seems as though Valentine is meant to be the character who reflects was we should be feeling, the conscience of the audience. In his few moments on screen, he says what we should say; he displays the disgust we should feel. But the character is, as mentioned, only on screen for a brief period. Thankfully. If the character did work, providing a Yang to balance Cage's Ying, the film would lose a significant amount of its dark humor. It's a small role and odd that they would use his name in the advertisements. <br /> <br />\\"Lord of War\\" is not a perfect film, but it is a memorable one and it contains a great performance from Nicholas Cage.  <br />

0316172324|2.0|Perhaps \\"Waste of Time\\" is a bit harsh of a description for this book.  While there are concepts and ideas inside that may be fresh to most people, some of the subjects Gladwell focuses on can be a bit boring or even a stretch to back up his point.  He talks about how Coke changed their formula after the Pepsi taste tests showed people in favor of Pepsi, and a police force that guns down a child they thought was pulling out a gun that was actually a wallet.<br /><br />In regards to the stories Gladwell uses to back himself up, he gets into explaining how our tastes change when we consume larger or smaller quantities of a product, which is why Pepsi fared better in taste tests.  He also got into how causing people to describe their feelings ended up changing the outcome of test results.  I guess he was trying to prove how initial feelings can be different than secondary ones, but is this really a new concept?<br /><br />In the beginning of the book there was something strange about him saying that he was only going to focus on what he calls \\"thin slicing\\" (a term he uses annoyingly often), and wasn't going to wander off into other topics.  Why would you have to say this to the reader?  I find when authors try setting up thier books in such a way, they end up straying from their original intended purpose as Gladwell greatly does.  While he says he spent a long time writing this book, the topics he chooses seem somewhat of a stretch to his original point that snap decisions are usually the best ones.<br /><br />What does all this tell us?  At the end I can't say I have a convincing argument as to how snap decisions (thin-slicing) are better.  In life I have found myself glad for not making quick decisions, rewarded by balancing all of the correct data.  I feel as if Gladwell could just as easily write a book as to why weighing all the options equally prove to be just as rewarding.

I've had the album almost a week now and STILL haven't listened to it all the way through (by contrast, when I downloaded Driving Rain off the internet, I had made several plays through in the first two days).<br /><br />The tracks I really don't like off Driving Rain, like \\"Back in the Sunshine,\\" \\"Your Way,\\" and \\"I Do,\\" these are the kind of fluff that fill this album.  It's supposed to be all inspiring and full of emotion?  Yeah... I guess if you strap on the accoustic and lightly play the piano, it makes it critically acclaimed.  The one Time critic said it was good the producer made Paul go solo on it.  I think there should be more Abe Laboriel and Rusty Anderson....<br /><br />I guess I sum it up this way... after hearing \\"Jenny Wren\\" and \\"English Tea,\\" it makes me wonder if we have another Paul imposter (ala a second \\"Paul is Dead\\" myth).... Because I can't see how these songs came from the same guy who did \\"Rinse the Raindrops,\\" \\"Hi, Hi, Hi,\\" and \\"Silly Love Songs.\\"

B00005JM8V|4.0|Because of the sheer length of this documentary and the number of topics covered, it's hard to pin down an exact analysis of it, since so much is going on.  I agree this is a historically important documentary, with many powerful scenes, both during interviews and just during scenes when the camera is wordlessly panning over what remains of the camps today.  Although it would be too easy and simplistic to just automatically give this a 5-star review and say it's the best most authorative film on the Shoah ever made.  This by no means covers nearly everything that happened during the Shoah, even in its massive length of nine and a half hours.  About the last hour is devoted to just the Warsaw Ghetto and the uprising, but apart from that the ghettoes aren't covered.  What this documentary does cover are five of the six Vernichtungslageren (annihiliation camps) in Poland--Treblinka, Sobib&oacute;r, Belzec, Chelmno, and Oswiecim (Auschwitz), and what happened to the people on their way there in the death wagons.  There are interviews with people on all sides--survivors (including the only two survivors of Chelmno, Simon Srebnik and Michael Podchlebnik), ghetto guards and bureaucrats, people who ran the camps (particularly Franz Suchomel of Treblinka), villagers who watched the death wagons coming and going (their reactions to these peoples' fate and what they claim to have done for them seems mixed), the survivors themselves, and the Polish diplomat Jan Karski, who had begged the world to stop the genocide he knew very well was going on.  Among the survivors interviewed was Rudolf Vrba, one of my heroes, who escaped Oswiecim on 7 April 1944 along with his friend Alfred Wetzler to try to warn the world about what was being planned for Hungarian Jewry.  Another big plus supporting this documentary is that it was made in 1985, when there were more survivors around, and most of them were younger than they are today.  And though some people might be turned off by how much of the film is in subtitles, I enjoyed hearing all of that German, French, Italian, Polish, and Hebrew, and felt my own listening comprehension of German vastly improving as the film wore on, at times barely needing the subtitles.<br /><br />All of that said, this film at times feels like it overshot the mark, since it covers so much ground even within that specific topic of the extermination camps in Poland, and yet doesn't really seem to be very structured.  Many times this documentary has a very nonlinear feel and composition, which at one level works since when dealing with something like the Shoah, all concepts of time and place really did become unimportant and nonlinear, but even so, it can also have the feeling of just jumping back and forth between interviews and footage.  For example, we return to several interviews a number of times after having had long stretches in between covering other things.  There were also some segments that could have been cut and didn't really belong there, like the dancing couple in the German nightclub.  For the entire documentary, information is merely being presented; no conclusions are drawn, no analyses made, no archival footage used.  Some people might feel this is just as appropriate a technique as having such a nonlinear structure, but after finding out what Ron Rosenbaum has to say about Monsieur Lanzmann in the book 'Explaining Hitler: The Search for the Origins of His Evil,' one is led to question why he used some of these techniques and why he doesn't feel there should be any analysis of the Shoah, no attempt to explain why these awful things happened or account for the great evil that took place, as though accounting for it somehow justifies it.<br /><br />Certainly this is an important film everyone should see at least once, but some of the effect is lessened by the lack of archival footage, the nonlinear structure and layout, and the refusal to draw any conclusions, make any analyses, provide any historical background for why these events were set in motion in the first place.  It's an important film about the Shoah, but by no means the most important one or the most authoritative one ever made.  The price also seems a little hefty; is it because of this film's huge reputation that it costs much more than most other four-disc sets?for why these events were set in motion in the first place.  It's an important film about the Shoah, but by no means the most important one or the most authoritative one ever made.  The price also seems a little hefty; is it because of this film's huge reputation that it costs much more than most other four-disc sets?

B000AL730O|5.0|Some might consider this \\"McCartney III,\\" because although Paul doesn't play all of the instruments on this album, he does play most of them. But Chaos & Creation is really the third (and best) in the \\"McCartney\\" series mostly because it's a very intimate work. We get a sense here that this is the real McCartney, up close and personal, not so much Sir Paul the entertainer.     And I say it's about time that Paul made a record that really matters, an album that connects to his listeners on an emotional level. It's a quiet, understated record exploring inner terrain in the same way as Bob Dylan's Time Out of Mind. Like Dylan and all the other rockers of his generation, Paul has aged. But like Dylan on that wonderful TOOM album, Paul is showing here that he's come to terms with his aging, and the wisdom that it brings. Too many people (to borrow a Paul phrase) have stopped taking Macca seriously as a great artist. This album reminds us that Paul wrote some of the great melancholy and reflective songs of the Beatles: Yesterday, I'll Follow the Sun, For No One, Eleanor Rigby, She's Leaving Home, Mother Nature's Son, Long & Winding Road. Most of Chaos & Creation has that kind of melancholy feeling. It's not a grandiose rock/pop album made for stadium/arena performance. Rather, this is a record for listening at home when one has the time to absorb the melodic beauty, harmonic brilliance, and lyrical sincerity of the songs.     This record is not perfect. First, many will miss Paul's more humorous, rocking side that albums like Band on the Run offer in abundance. Chaos & Creation is not a balanced album in that regard, it's certainly tilted to the quiet and reflective side. Secondly, there are a couple of clunkers like \\"Too Much Rain\\" that simply don't hold up. But the rest of the album is original and challenging for McCartney. Obviously, Nigel Godrich did a great job in pulling Macca out of himself to get the most inspired performances and writing on tape.    Fine Line isa strong opener, the most upbeat rocker on the album, yet with a surprising lyrical perspective...Macca is talking to a male friend, a brother, who has gone astray. The chord progression has an oddly engaging dissonance, very intriguing and catchy, and it gets under your skin right away. How Kind of You is unsettling in its emotional frankness. I've rarely heard Paul this self-effacing, and it's a refreshing revelation. The melody matches the yearning quality of the lyrics. Jenny Wren, At the Mercy, two more masterworks. Jenny Wren has the delicate acoustic finger-picking style of Blackbird and Mother Nature's Son, with an equally poignant lyric about a heartbroken girl. At the Mercy is one of the sadder songs on the album, with a deeply haunting melody that darkly mirrors its bleak world view.     Then comes a true delight! Friends to Go was apparently written as a tribute to George Harrison, and how wonderful a tribute it is! Paul captures the bouncy harmonic style of George in the music, but even more fittingly, Paul evokes George's shy, self-effacing nature in the lyrics. This is perhaps the most knowing tribute that Paul or anyone could have conceived for George, because it's exactly the kind of song that George himself would write--although Paul pulls it off without sounding like he's imitating George. One of the loveliest Macca songs ever, and one of the highlights of the album. My eyes have welled with tears a few times already, hearing this and picturing George. The two men had their quarrels, but they were brothers who grew up together under the public glare of Beatlemania, and Paul shows just how much he loved George, and also how much he understood George's musical and personal style, by writing this song. Very moving in a subtle way.     Speaking of his former bandmates, Riding to Vanity Fair is Lennon-esque in its raw emotional bitterness, and it actually reminds me of Lennon's anti-Paul tirade, How Do You Sleep, with less of the sardonic venom, but with the same core of hurt. Vanity Fair is one of the most surprising McCartney songs. I've rarely heard Paul communicate with such open invective. The music has a brooding quality, with the hushed intensity of the strings and the haunting tinkling of the glockenspiel, that conveys the tortured emotion. Lyrically, Paul is bidding good riddance to a friend who has betrayed him and hurt him deeply. How refreshing to know that Macca still has such surprises within him as a writer.     The final two tracks are less melancholy, but more focused on the lush romanticism that Paul thrives upon, with stunningly gorgeous melodies, and heartfelt lyrics. This Never Happened Before is probably the loveliest melody on the entire album, a piano-driven chord progression that is right up there alongside Here There & Everywhere or Maybe I'm Amazed for its pure unadulterated beauty. This is a classic McCartney love ballad in every sense, with all of the good qualities and none of the drawbacks. Macca said he \\"loaned it out\\" to a couple getting married, and that makes sense: it's an ideal wedding song, as heavenly as it gets. The closing track, Anyway, is also a love song, with a darker melodic feel than the previous song, and with yearning lyrics and vocals to match the music. It's a great closer for the album, because it leaves an open door, an unanswered question. It reminds me, in fact, of the closing track on Ram, Back Seat of My Car, in the grandeur of the melody and the wistful romanticism of the lyrics.     A very thought-provoking album, in fact the most challenging album of Macca's entire solo career. It's not a \\"rock\\" album, but it is the most heartfelt collection of songs Paul has ever squeezed onto one album since the Beatles--quite an achievement. At this stage of his career, when many of us thought Paul was an afterthought, this is one hell of a comeback, another similarity to Dylan's Time Out of Mind. And like that album, Paul deserves a Grammy for this.
B000063JZQ|5.0|A flop in its day, Polanski's The Tragedy of MacBeth now looks more and more like one of his finest achievements. Unlike many Shakespeare adaptations, Polanski opts for clarity and accessibility rather than elocutionary gymnastics, providing a brisk narrative and staging it with a real cinematic imagination that prevents it from ever becoming stage bound. It's set in a believable, gritty world where the setting sun makes the very sands look bathed in blood and overcast skies and harsh elements provide an appropriate setting for betrayal and violence - LOTS of violence. Despite moments of black humor, it's pretty obvious what Polanski is trying to get out of his system in scenes of brutal murder or the ripping of MacDuff from his mother's womb. Francesca Annis doesn't quite scale the heights of madness as Lady MacBeth, but Jon Finch and Martin Shaw do well by MacBeth and Banquo and the supporting performances are pleasingly naturalistic. The use of location is excellent and well-served by Gilbert Taylor's Scope photography, while Third Eye Blind's scoring is surprisingly apt. Definitely one of the best Shakespeare screen adaptations, and a real movie as well.
0783117523|5.0|Was a great movie! Sad and realistic of how drug addiction ruins your life!
0790729407|5.0|Michael Cimino was one of many who tried to bring the story of Irish revolutionary Michael Collins to the screen and on the evidence of the mess he made of Salvatore HGiuliano's story in The Siclian (and the bizarre gay love triangle in his proposed version) it's a good job he didn't. Kevin Costner's attempts resulted in some equally simplistic scripts that enshrined cliche over history before Warners decided to drop his version in favor of Neil Jordan's long-planned film. Even if they were motivated more by the success of Interview With the Vampire than the material, they made the right choice: Michael Collins is easily one of Jordan's very best films and a strikingly intelligent piece of political cinema. There are changes for dramatic purposes, but these generally seem made for sound reasons and don't change the essential truth of the Irish Republican hero who became a scapegoat for de Valera's failure to gain a Republic and ended up being assassinated by his former colleagues in Ireland's forgotten and bloody civil war.  <br /> <br />Clocking in at little over 130 minutes, Jordan keeps a sense of momentum that occasionally loses the odd detail that would be helpful to audiences unfamiliar with Irish history (such as the way the popular hatred towards the rebels who fought in the Easter Rising was turned around by the disastrous decision of the British to execute its leaders) but which still manages to find room for character as well, personalizing the tragedy surprisingly effectively. One of the last historical epics to use real sets and real extras instead of CGI, the film feels grounded in reality while still being an enthralling and cinematic political thriller. Sinead O'Connor's screaming over the assassination scene is unhelpful, but even that can't destroy the film. <br /> <br />Keeping his promise to cast Liam Neeson despite heavy lobbying from Michael Collins lookalike Kenneth Branagh (who lacks the presence necessary for the part), Jordan gets good rather than great performances from his leads, although Alan Rickman nails de Valera's  reptilian and hesitant delivery and Ian Hart impresses as one of Collins' lieutenants. The unwelcome presence of Julia Roberts threatens to turn the film into Hollywood but thankfully her extremely limited abilities aren't stretched to breaking point. Probably the only film about the IRA that protestants and Brits can see without bringing Molotov cocktails to the cinema, it's release fell foul of America's constant denial of the complexities of the situation, Ireland's denial of the civil war and the rest of the world's horror at the IRA breaking their ceasefire without warning and killing a little girl in the process. Rarely revived, it's definitely worth rediscovering. <br /> <br />The DVD comes with an excellent South Bank Show that fills in many of the film's historical gaps, including archive footage of Collins himself (who really was a dead ringer for Branagh), although it is irritatingly a flipper disc. <br /> <br />

B0002KVULG|4.0|There's more than just a touch of disco to Frank Langella's costumes in John Badham's 1979 Dracula, and along with the copious amounts of dry ice accompanying his seductions and a Maurice Binder laser light love scene it occasionally hovers on the edge of turning into Saturday Bite Fever. But this is more of a lavishly mounted old-school interpretation, with W.D. Richter's screenplay reworking both the novel and the stage play to interesting effect: the film is set entirely in England, bracketed by two violent scenes at sea, and Dracula here is more of a serial seducer than a creature of the night. But by emphasizing the Byronic seductiveness of the role there's never an real sense of menace or threat: this Dracula is more like that smooth git who steals your girlfriend at a nightclub than the embodiment of evil, and it's only in the snarling violence of the finale that you get a sense of the animal beneath. That the forces of good are such a lifeless lot doesn't help much either: Laurence Olivier isn't quite as embarrassingly OTT as my memory had him, and Donald Pleasance's habit of eating in his every scene isn't as tiresome on the small screen as the large, but along with Trevor Eve's ey-upp lad northern lawyer type Jonathan Harker they don't exactly have you cheering them on. But despite the problems, the films is full of great little moments, such as the Count clawing away at the putty in a window to get to his first victim, boasts beautiful production design (the shipwreck and Carfax Abbey are particularly impressive) and has a wonderful romantic score by John Williams. The eagle-eyed will spot future Doctor Who and holder of the Guinness World Record for stuffing live ferrets down his trousers (it's genuine: look it up) Sylvester McCoy in a cough-and-a-spit part.    Sadly, the transfer on both Universal's DVD and their subsequent Blu-ray release loses the rich colour of the theatrical release for the prefered desaturated near-black and white look Badham originally wanted - one of those occasions where you can't help but agree with the studio, I'm afraid. Boosting the colour controls on your TV won't help either: parts of the film, like the establishing shot of Whitby Harbour, have no colour at all to boost, and the desaturation has been accompanied by a lack of background detail. The retrospective documentary on the Region 1 NTSC DVD and region-free Blu-ray is interesting and informative, but the photo gallery is poorly presented and the absence of the original trailer is disappointing.

B00004XONN|5.0|The musical evolution that occurred over Radiohead's first four records culminated with 2000's \\"Kid A.\\" After debuting with the lo-fi indie-rock of 1993's \\"Pablo Honey,\\" Radiohead metamorphosed from polished, melodic alternative rock (1995's \\"The Bends\\") into commercially viable progressive rock (1997's \\"OK Computer\\") before arriving at \\"Kid A,\\" uncompromising art rock almost completely stripped of mainstream sensibilities.  Trace the similar progress of the earliest Yes and Genesis records, and you'll easily see why Radiohead appeals to progressive rock fans. Radiohead perhaps forfeited short-term commercial success with \\"Kid A\\" (although it did debut on Billboard's charts at #1), but this record may stand the test of time better than any other Radiohead album.  Thirty years from now, music fans may speak of \\"Kid A\\" the way they now do about Yes' \\"Close to the Edge\\" or Pink Floyd's \\"Dark Side of the Moon.\\" <br /> <br />\\"Kid A\\" represents a re-constructionist approach to rock.  Radiohead turns the idiom inside out without entirely eliminating the traditional elements of the rock band. Few songs on \\"Kid A\\" rely on conventional song structures; exceptions include the hard-rocking \\"The National Anthem\\" and the relatively accessible \\"Optimistic.\\"  \\"Kid A\\" undoubtedly demands repeated listening: first to scratch its icy surface, then to gain access to the labyrinths of sound that lie underneath.  The cover art brilliantly illustrates the record: ice-cold to the touch, \\"Kid A\\" burns with energizing fires within. <br /> <br />For all the precision of composition and performance, \\"Kid A\\" possesses the power to emotionally affect the listener. The ethereal \\"Everything In Its Right Place\\" opens the record with a palpable sense of excitement. Exhilaration sets in with \\"The National Anthem,\\" and segues into introspection with the dreamlike, Floydian strains of \\"How to Disappear Completely.\\"  \\"Idioteque\\" is imbued with apocalyptic fear, while \\"Morning Bell\\" delivers a feeling ofanxiety with its disconcerting 5/4 beat.  The record achieves a melancholic catharsis with the dirge-like finale, \\"Motion Picture Soundtrack.\\"   <br /> <br />Throughout \\"Kid A,\\" Radiohead expand their sonic palette with evocative synthesizers, vocal samples, experimental effects and drum loops. Amidst this varied tone color, Thom Yorke's plaintive, elastic falsetto is perhaps the most expressive instrument of all. <br /> <br />With \\"Kid A,\\" Radiohead has produced a work of imagination that extends and transcends the limitations of the rock genre.  This is an achievement of nearly unparalleled artistic integrity whose reputation is sure to grow with time.
0345440900|4.0|Being a first time Mum you soon realise that everybody you talk to is an 'expert' and apparently has the answers to all your 'problems'. 0060922583|5.0|As there have already been many reviews concerning the ideas advanced by Michael Talbot in his profoundly influential book The Holographic Universe, I want to refrain from reiterating them. Instead, I'll comment upon a number of reviews that only underline the continuing need for such books, and speak of those times when religion and science were virtually one and the same. The tales and memories of outrageous abuses committed in serving that worldview may be what continue to dissuade many scientists and realists from embracing a reinformed version of that genuinely troubled - and troubling - marriage.    Yet science has become, in so many ways, just another religion, choked off by the same dogma that holds our species hostage to a diminished, controlling idea of the reason for our being, Like religion, science is defined by a collection of beliefs that are substantiated within the context and boundaries of accepted understanding, failing to imagine that there are demonstrable answers and additional information to be had beyond them. But as with religion, science so often falls short because it cannot acknowledge the diversity of human - life - experience, that many outcomes cannot be repeated due to our beliefs affecting them, the most powerful notion that The Holographic Universe explores in every kind of light. This is also what allows joyless and dreary showmen such as James 'The Amazing' Randi to take advantage of similarly unquestioning skeptics, creating a cynical, self-fulfilling prophecy. It is truly terrifying to contemplate that others can exert such power over the direction of events in our lives as would a voodoo practitioner or kahuna (although both work in response to their victims' belief capacity) yet as with the clarity of purpose and direction that follows so many near-death experiences (including those of Talbot's) the awareness of this capability and how it relates to our true multidimensional nature (that, as the book suggests, of all matter) results in a self-policing sense of  responsibility that rarely falls prey to material need or weaknesses. The inherent (and somewhat irrational) fear of this demonstrates a distinct lack of faith in humankind's capacity to evolve.     What is faith? It is not another term for religion itself, but instead the spiritual maturing of a fundamental belief system, the butterfly of elegant understanding that emerges from a rough-hewn cocoon. More than anything else, spirituality is a recognition of relationships and interconnectedness, common origins in the energetic realm; faith, the belief that there are answers to every question posed, and that they are available to every person. Science also requires some faith, at least a belief, in the viability of a theory or hypothesis.  When what came to be modern science rose up during the Rennaissance as a reaction to an unenlightened Dark Age (yet not necessarily giving the lie to alchemy, a very misunderstood pursuit to this day) it was attended by curious, extraordinarily driven individuals such as Leonardo da Vinci, Galileo, Copernicus and even Sir Isaac Newton whose creative tendencies led them to rarely-visited paths of inquiry and what were then decidedly radical ideas. The atrophying of just such a creative process and the aforementioned fear of abuse is what prevents many of us from attending the remarriage of science and faith, failing to make the distinction between the latter and religion.     Nearly fifteen years ago, The Holographic Universe strongly suggested that marriage needn't forever be an unhappy one and can give life to a far richer view of just what Man and matter truly are, help us to visualize a more meaningful existence, seen through the eyes of both.
B000077VPU|5.0|Fast and reliable service it was shipped the same day that I ordered.
B000002OZY|4.0|I'm really not here to write a review of the music; there's already 181 out here alone.  However I'm disappointed that Amazon's editorial review implies this is the first \\"rock opera\\" giving no mention whatsoever to the Pretty Things, and pure misinformation such as provided by another reviewer here from Africa.  Sir, what are you talking about?  You state that Sorrow is \\"virtually the exact same story as Tommy\\".  Please, I look forward to your comparative analysis.  There is no comparison outside that they are both psychedelic, The Pretty Things much more so.  Tommy is much more deranged and twisted.  \\"Maria\\" offers a more honest opinion and I agree, EVERYONE should check out \\"S.F.Sorrow\\" if you have not already; it really is worth a listen.  I've known the album for decades and it is a true treat for headphones. <br /> <br />One last thing to clarify though, it is true that The Pretty Things' \\"S.F.Sorrow\\" was recorded and released in 1968, in ENGLAND.  In the USA it was released on Rare Earth records, label #RS-506, which was in August, 1969.  \\"Tommy\\" was released in the US on May 17, 1969.  Who came first?  In the States, \\"Tommy\\" really WAS the first rock opera - but in reality The Pretty Things did do it first, Pete acknowledged in several interviews that he was inspired by it, however the writing is no \\"rip-off\\", it is pure Townshend.  The Pretty Things is pure Phil May, however it's really not quite as strong and coherent as Pete's - but honestly in my opinion musically more interesting and a joy to listen to.  Pete is delightfully twisted, and Phil is delightfully wasted... take your pick.

B0007QJ1MU|4.0|Ever since Kyuss, Josh Homme has been an interesting and inventive musician.  He has found a nice home in QOTSA, which has become more an ongoing project than a band.  Anyone who has followed QOTSA will know that the core lineup has changed several times (recently with the departure of bassist Nick Oliveri) and that albums have increasingly featured guest appearances by outsiders. <br /> <br />The project/rotating lineup/guest appearance aspect of QOTSA is more evident on Lullabies to Paralyze than previous albums, in my opinion.  This is not to say the album is uneven or lacks a solid theme, however.  Homme clearly had an idea where this record was going, but you can definitely get the sense that many musical minds were involved in its production.  Somehow, the music on this disc has infectious hooks without being pop; it has a classic and nostalgic air without being overtly retro; it's inventive without being pretentious.  As always, QOTSA delivers. <br /> <br />Highlights (discounting the single \\"Little Sister\\") are \\"Burn the Witch\\" (featuring ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons and Jack Black [that's right... from Tenacious D and School of Rock]), \\"I Never Came\\" (which is just *different* and *good*), and \\"Someone's In the Wolf\\" (great dynamics and atmosphere, and with an interesting video on the DVD that accompanies the CD). <br /> <br />New listeners may find this album a bit quirky.  Those coming from the punk end of things should consider earlier albums (esp. Rated R).  Those with mainstream tastes who can't get \\"Little Sister\\" out of their heads should consider picking up Songs For the Deaf as a slightly more accessible disc. <br /> <br />I highly recommend QOTSA in general and this album. <br /> <br />
B000AL730O|5.0|I've been a Beatles fan since 1964 and never get tired or hearing their music.  I haven't liked most of what McCartney has done over the last 35 years.  His songs often sound like careless, throw-away melodies.  Driving Rain was a low point.  Before this album, my favorite was Tug of War.  What these two albums seem to have in common is a strong producer and good arrangements for the songs.  On first hearing, the songs on this album sound somewhat thin, but after repeated listenings the album starts to grab you.  Overall, it's now my favorite McCartney album.

0393970116|5.0|In this 1910 story of Edwardian England, Forster illustrates the conflicts between the superior attitudes of the aristocracy and a developing feeling of obligation toward the \\"lower\\" classes which World War I will soon bring into sharp relief. Margaret and Helen Schlegel are intellectual and sensitive to the arts, with compassionate hearts for those less fortunate.<br /><br />When Margaret, at age twenty-nine, is affianced to a much older widower, Henry Wilcox, this conflict of attitudes is brought to the fore. Henry, insensitive and believing himself actually entitled to his family's privileges, is cold and reserved, though Margaret believes that \\"Henry must be forgiven and made better by love.\\"<br /><br />Helen, her sister, a 21-year-old with an enthusiasm for the life of the imagination, has no sympathy for Henry's staid pronouncements and failure to pay attention to the people \\"below him\\" who are dependent upon his whims. When a young clerk finds himself out of his bank job as a result of something Henry has said, Henry refuses his wife's entreaties to give the destitute Leonard a job.<br /><br />Immensely sympathetic to the economic position of the poor and women, Forster illustrates their financial dependence on others. Margaret, who secures the reader's total sympathy, must try to educate a close-minded dolt like Henry, but she achieves only limited success. Later, his belief that Helen reflects negatively upon himself and his family inspires a disaster with far-reaching consequences.<br /><br />Filled with incisive observations and great wit, the novel follows the narrative pattern of a melodrama, but Forster's sensitivity to both sides--the practical and conservative values of Henry vs. the emotional and idealistic sides of Margaret and Helen--elevates the novel above the tawdry.  With the action centered around the Wilcox home at Howard's End, the reader realizes that the estate is a microcosm for the conflicts of the nation.<br /><br />This edition, thoroughly annotated, is the definitive critical edition containing resource material and an explication of references.  Comprehensive background material for the period, critical analysis of Forster's themes, and careful notes throughout this novel provide a wealth of research materials for the literary critic and historian.  Mary Whippleedition, thoroughly annotated, is the definitive critical edition containing resource material and an explication of references.  Comprehensive background material for the period, critical analysis of Forster's themes, and careful notes throughout this novel provide a wealth of research materials for the literary critic and historian.  Mary Whipple <br />
B000002O4X|5.0|Wonderful CD.  Enjoy listening to it regularly.  It's very relaxing, too.
B000252NAI|5.0|Paying homage to the Nat Cole Trio, the most popular jazz combo of its day, Diana Krall (piano), Russell Malone (guitar), and Paul Keller (bass) bring some long-time favorites and some lesser known Cole Trio hits to life. The arrangements are terrific, ranging from slow, bluesy numbers, to swing, a torchy ballad, and forties-style jive. In every case, the emphasis is on the trio, and though Krall sings on every track, more than half of each song is instrumental, with extended solos on piano by Krall and guitar by Russell Malone.<br /><br />Krall's voice is a full, sometimes husky, alto with very little vibrato, and though she can sing scat, and does on \\"Frim Fram Sauce,\\" she is at her best singing slow songs of aching loss, where, occasionally, her phrasing reminds me of Sarah Vaughan. \\"Gee, Baby, Ain't I Good to You,\\" sung slower than Cole did it, is a sad, bluesy number with wonderful, casual jazz piano riffs. \\"Boulevard of Broken Dreams,\\" my favorite on the album, is torchy, the imagined tears kept under control as Krall pines for lost love, with the piano ranging into chromatic variations. In \\"You Call It Madness\\" and \\"I'm Through With Love,\\" Krall keeps her voice whispery, singing slowly, almost confidentially, as she maintains the slow beat and melancholy mood. By contrast, \\"Hit That Jive, Jack,\\" moves in a quick, toe-tapping rhythm, as Krall, Malone, and Keller sing together and have fun.<br /><br />The album has plenty of variety to the selections and features three fine jazz instrumentalists who toured together and perfected their ensemble for several months before recording this album. With the earthy voice of Krall added to the instrumental mix, this album is certainly one of Krall's best--a huge success. There are no drums here (except on \\"Boulevard of Broken Dreams\\"), but that is not a limitation, and, in fact, may be an advantage, since the listener's attention remains focused on the tunefulness of the songs and their jazz variations. This is a fine homage to the Nat Cole Trio, which would have been justly proud of Krall's recording. Mary Whippleine homage to the Nat Cole Trio, which would have been justly proud of Krall's recording. Mary Whipple <br />

B00002Z88D|5.0|Some fans, who thought making an album with an orchestra was a sell-out, thought \\"S&M\\" was a career killer. I, however, think it's a very creative and interesting idea. Metallica are the first ever(and only) metal band to attempt performing a concert (21 songs) with an orchestra sitting in, so there's no denying that this album is also innovative.<br /><br />And, if you ask me, they pulled this album off nicely. While the electric guitars sometimes drown out the San Francisco Orchestra, the violins, trumpets, and timpani usually make the songs sound fuller and make some boring parts interesting.<br /><br />Plus, even though some fans hated Metallica for making this album, \\"S&M\\" did make them even more famous, and helped expand their listening audience. And, as the old saying goes: any publicity is good publicity.<br /><br />This concert's set list consists of songs from \\"Ride the Lightning\\" to \\"Reload.\\" I think Metallica chose not to include any \\"Kill `Em All\\" songs because they didn't think the orchestra could keep up with that album's insanely fast riffing.<br /><br />Song ratings for disc one:<br /><br />1. \\"The Ecstacy of Gold\\": A cool, ominous introductory track. It sounds pretty, but it's too short. 6/10.<br />2. \\"Call of the Ktulu\\": The violins are really audible on this track, but so the guitars and drums are prominent, too. This is one of the many songs where the orchestra works well with Metallica, and the guitar solo is also still included. 10/10.<br />3. \\"Master of Puppets\\": This song sounds quite a bit different, here. First of all, frontman James Hatfield's vocals are deeper than they were when he first sang this song. Also, in addition to some trumpets making an entrance, James sometimes trades off vocal parts with the crowd. Finally, James drops an \\"f word\\" before one of the choruses. This expletive was (obviously) not in the original song, and it comes across sounding rather random, here. This isn't a bad song, but I just prefer the original. 8/10.<br />4. \\"Of Wolf and Man\\": The violins go well with the low, pounding guitars, and help make the beginning of this song have a dark vibe. Near the end, James asks us \\"Got any wolves out there?,\\" and then he lets loose a big howl. 10/10.<br />5. \\"The Thing That Should Not Be\\": The heavy guitars usually drown out the orchestra in this song, and I enjoy how James laughs maniacally when he sings the \\"sanity\\" line. 8/10.<br />6. \\"Fuel\\": The guitars and drums charge straight ahead, and the orchestra really helps \\"fuel\\" and add energy to this song's rhythm. This song is possibly more energetic and all around better than the original. 10/10.<br />7. \\"The Memory Remains\\": I don't like how the crowd kind of takes over the vocal parts on this song, because you can't really understand what they're saying. Other than that, though, this is a good song; I enjoy how it ends with clapping and some classical-sounding strings. 8/10.<br />8. \\"No Leaf Clover\\": The creaky violin strings go well with the opening, soft guitar strums, and I enjoy how the violins play in between the pounding, bobbing guitar riffs at the end. 10/10.<br />9. \\"Hero Of The Day\\": This whole song, especially the beginning, could make better use of the orchestra. This song needs some spicing up. 6/10.<br />10. \\"Devil's Dance\\": I enjoy the ominous sounding violins and trumpets at the beginning of this song. This is a very catchy tune, and the orchestra gives it an extra punch. 9/10.<br />11. \\"Bleeding Me\\": The violins again make this song sound fuller and richer, and Kirk's guitar solo is as good, here, as it was on the original version. Unfortunately, this song is a little too long and boring in parts. 7/10.<br /><br />Disc two:<br /><br />1. \\"Nothing Else Matters\\": There's a cool flute-sounding instrument, and it helps to add some atmosphere to the beginning, but, other than that, the orchestra doesn't really add much to this song. 8/10.<br />2. \\"Until It Sleeps\\": This is a good metal song; it gains momentum well,but the orchestra should have been left out of this one. 7/10.<br />3. \\"For Whom The Bell Tolls\\": The violins ride the beat well, on this song. The orchestra plays at the same time as the guitars, thus making this song, in my opinion, sound better than the original. 10/10.<br />4. \\"Minus Human\\": The orchestra is really accentuated and blends well into this song's heavy, punching guitars. Unfortunately, this song ends kind of suddenly, and it sounds rather incomplete. 8/10.<br />5. \\"Wherever I May Roam\\": This is a great, classic metal song, but the violins sound kind of forced, here, like the orchestra felt like they needed to be included. 8/10.<br />6. \\"Outlaw Torn\\": The orchestra sounds right at home, here. It makes a nice, twinkling sound at the beginning, and the rest of the song has a good friction between the soft and heavy parts. 10/10.<br />7. \\"Sad But True\\": This song sounds louder and heavier, here, than the original, studio version, and there's some excellent violin playing, which make for some good background noise. 10/10.<br />8. \\"One\\": A great song in the `80's, and it's great live, too. The highlight of this song is when the trumpets begin and play with Lars' double bass drumming. 10/10.<br />9. \\"Enter Sandman\\": The riffs and rhythm of this song is as catchy as the original, and the violins again add some ear candy, but I kind of wish James sing during the chorus. It's a nice touch, too, when the song pauses briefly, near the end, for a couple of orchestral solos. 10/10.<br />10. \\"Battery\\": Almost as good as the original. Almost. I don't like the beginning, when the violins kind of drown out the acoustic guitars. 8/10.<br /><br />So, the orchestra works better in some places than others, but this C.D. is, overall, quite great. \\"S&M\\" is easily Metallica's most innovative album since 1986's \\"Master of Puppets,\\" and it has a set list of songs that kind of make this C.D. an unorthodox \\"Greatest Hits\\" album for Metallica. It's a good place to start for newcomers, and a great inclusion in every Metallica diehard's collection.<br /><br />\\"S&M\\" is a little bit too long (it's over 132 minutes in length), so you might want to listen to this album in stages, before you become bored with it.<br /><br />In conclusion, this is one of the best live albums I own, and even if you don't like it, you should at least give Metallica props for attempting something which was so risky and experimental.violins ride the beat well, on this song. The orchestra plays at the same time as the guitars, thus making this song, in my opinion, sound better than the original. 10/10.  4. \\"Minus Human\\": The orchestra is really accentuated and blends well into this song's heavy, punching guitars. Unfortunately, this song ends kind of suddenly, and it sounds rather incomplete. 8/10.  5. \\"Wherever I May Roam\\": This is a great, classic metal song, but the violins sound kind of forced, here, like the orchestra felt like they needed to be included. 8/10.  6. \\"Outlaw Torn\\": The orchestra sounds right at home, here. It makes a nice, twinkling sound at the beginning, and the rest of the song has a good friction between the soft and heavy parts. 10/10.  7. \\"Sad But True\\": This song sounds louder and heavier, here, than the original, studio version, and there's some excellent violin playing, which make for some good background noise. 10/10.  8. \\"One\\": A great song in the `80's, and it's great live, too. The highlight of this song is when the trumpets begin and play with Lars' double bass drumming. 10/10.  9. \\"Enter Sandman\\": The riffs and rhythm of this song is as catchy as the original, and the violins again add some ear candy, but I kind of wish James sing during the chorus. It's a nice touch, too, when the song pauses briefly, near the end, for a couple of orchestral solos. 10/10.  10. \\"Battery\\": Almost as good as the original. Almost. I don't like the beginning, when the violins kind of drown out the acoustic guitars. 8/10.    So, the orchestra works better in some places than others, but this C.D. is, overall, quite great. \\"S&M\\" is easily Metallica's most innovative album since 1986's \\"Master of Puppets,\\" and it has a set list of songs that kind of make this C.D. an unorthodox \\"Greatest Hits\\" album for Metallica. It's a good place to start for newcomers, and a great inclusion in every Metallica diehard's collection.     \\"S&M\\" is a little bit too long (it's over 132 minutes in length), so you might want to listen to this album in stages, before you become bored with it.     In conclusion, this is one of the best live albums I own, and even if you don't like it, you should at least give Metallica props for attempting something which was so risky and experimental.
B00002Z88D|4.0|First of all, I have to admit that I don't own this CD, (yet).  So to be honest, I haven't actually listened to this recording.  BUT, I DID, watch the concert on PBS, and it was amazing!!  If you get a chance to see it, watch it!  And if it's available on DVD, buy it!  Trust me, it's worth it.  You can't imagine the energy and electricity in that concert hall that night.  This is something the band had wanted to do for quite some time, but for whatever reason, didn't persue.  So oddly enough, it was the conductor of the San Francisco Symphany that approached them.  Because the idea of playing with a symphany behind them was new and challenging, and something they had been wanting to do...AND because there was skeptisism and pressure to pull this off, they put everything into it!   Trust me, you've never seen them like this!  It was the LIVE concert of their lives!  Metallica's last few albums (from Metallica, the \\"Black\\" album on) have been so brilliantly produced, that I really didn't think they could sound any better.  I was wrong.  The merging of electric guitars, drums, and Hetfield's voice, to a symphany of of musicians and instruments is pure musical genius, and an absolute masterpiece!  You won't believe how incredibly the two blend together, and also feed off of each other.  While I was watching, I could see the give and take of intensity from the band, and then the symphany.  It was like a game of tennis, back and forth, back and forth...building and building.  Awesome!!True, there were some white-headed, season ticket holders that walked out in a huff, horrified that a \\"Heavy Metal Rock Band\\" had infultrated their precious concert hall.  But they were the minority, most stayed.  And of the open minded ticket holders surprised to see a heavy metal rock band playing with their symphany, a great many of them were won over by the performance. And I'll bet quite a few even became Metallica fans.  This is quite the collaberation.  The classical elligence, and sophistication of a symphany, combined with the, experimental honesty, and edge of a rock band.  We haven't seen anything like this, since the boy with the chocolate bumped into the girl with the peanut butter.  And we all know how well that turned out!  Honestly, this is like night and day.  But it works.  The music is intense, and beautiful, and it's all very dramatic and inspiring.  I've never seen anything quite like it.    If you're already a Metallica fan, you know their talent. But if you've only heard their studio albums, you're missing out, because they've stepped it up here.  I'm telling you, you need to hear this!  If you're new to Metallica, you won't be disappointed with this CD.  It's Metallica at their best...their most energized...and backed by other world class musicians!I'm so impressed with what I saw and heard.  And I'm so excited that they put their performance on CD.  My only beef, and the only reason I couldn't give this 5 stars, is because they left off one crucial song.  The song I looked this CD up for, \\"Fade to Black\\".  I'm very disappointed they didn't include their amazing version of \\"Fade to Black\\" from that night.  Hetfield's guitar solo's were very long and haunting.  And it was magnified by the darkness in the concert hall while he played.  And as his solo ended, perfectly on cue the symphany came thundering in.  It was incredible, it gave me goosebumps. This was the most memorable, most amazing song they did that night...and it's not on here.  That's a crime.  Guys, if you're listening?  If you ever re-release this CD, or need to add a song to a studio album, I'm begging you right now!  Please, for the love of god, and all that's holy, put \\"Fade to Black\\" from the San Francisco Symphany concert on there!  Put it on twice!!  Ok?  Cool. Thanks. :)Get this CD.  'Nuff said.

B00004XONN|5.0|This album emcompasses my `musical coming-of-age,' specifically because it's one of the most atmospheric albums ever recorded, and also an absolute masterpiece. It's a slick, multi-layered, and beautifully structured mixture of rock and electronica that reveals an entirely new dimension of Radiohead's capabilities and talent: starting with the piano driven Everything in Its Right Place, to the dreamlike Motion Picture Soundtrack, the band cycles through various styles and combinations, and does that quite successfully, if not perfectly. This album is especially significant for me because it's about subtleties; the excruciating amount of detail I heard on each and every track on this album completely blew my mind. There isn't any particular moment of distinctiveness; everything meshes delicately into one experience. This album is smart and well crafted, and it forever changed the spectrum of music I listened to. Everything loud suddenly turned to everything subtle, heavy riffs turned to delicate melodies, and my definition of music became something simpler to listen to, and infinitely more difficult to write.
